claim: Ninjas likely wore clothing that helped them blend into their surroundings, rather than all black as often depicted in popular culture.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that ninjas often operated in rural and forested areas, making dark blue or brown clothing more practical for blending in than pure black.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that ninjas often operated in rural and forested areas, making dark blue or brown clothing more practical for blending in than pure black.
Some historical depictions and folklore describe ninjas wearing black clothing to blend into shadows during nighttime operations.
Nighttime operations were less common than daytime activities, making dark blue or brown more practical for most scenarios.
The association of ninjas with black clothing is deeply rooted in theater and popular culture, which may have exaggerated historical accuracy.
Historical records from the Edo period explicitly mention ninjas using dark blue or brown garments, supporting the practicality argument.

supporting.text: Black clothing stands out in natural environments during daylight, whereas muted earth tones would provide better camouflage, aligning with ninjas' need for stealth.

attacks.text: Black clothing stands out in natural environments during daylight, whereas muted earth tones would provide better camouflage, aligning with ninjas' need for stealth.
Historical records suggest ninjas often operated at night, where black clothing would provide better camouflage than earth tones.
Even at night, pure black is rare in nature, and dark blues or browns would blend better with shadows and foliage.
Ninjas sometimes disguised themselves as civilians or farmers, requiring non-stealthy clothing, making camouflage colors irrelevant in those situations.
Disguises were situational, but stealth-focused missions would still prioritize camouflage, supporting the original argument.

supporting.text: Textile analysis from the Edo period shows that dark blue (indigo-dyed) fabrics were more commonly available and durable than black, making them a likely choice for practical use.

attacks.text: Textile analysis from the Edo period shows that dark blue (indigo-dyed) fabrics were more commonly available and durable than black, making them a likely choice for practical use.
While dark blue was common, historical records also mention ninjas using black clothing for nighttime operations where blending into shadows was critical.
Black dye was indeed rare, but ninjas may have used soot or charcoal to darken their clothing when necessary, bypassing the need for expensive black fabrics.
The durability of dark blue fabric does not necessarily mean it was preferred for stealth; functionality may have been secondary to concealment in certain missions.
Surviving ninja manuals emphasize adaptability over rigid clothing choices, suggesting they used whatever best suited the environment, including black when needed.

supporting.text: Ninjas were trained to adapt to their surroundings, suggesting they would have worn clothing appropriate to the environment, which varied and was rarely uniformly black.

attacks.text: Ninjas were trained to adapt to their surroundings, suggesting they would have worn clothing appropriate to the environment, which varied and was rarely uniformly black.
Historical records and artistic depictions from the Edo period often show ninjas in dark or black clothing, suggesting a standardized appearance.
The dark clothing in artistic depictions may have been symbolic or exaggerated for dramatic effect, not reflecting actual ninja attire.
Ninjas sometimes operated at night, making black clothing practical for stealth regardless of the environment.
Even at night, environments have varied shades and textures, so adaptive camouflage would still be more effective than pure black.

supporting.text: Artistic depictions of ninjas in black clothing became popular in theater and later films, but these were stylized rather than historically accurate representations.

attacks.text: Artistic depictions of ninjas in black clothing became popular in theater and later films, but these were stylized rather than historically accurate representations.

Historical records from the Edo period describe ninjas wearing dark blue or brown clothing for nighttime camouflage, not black, supporting the claim that their attire was practical rather than theatrical.
Some historical scrolls and manuals, such as the Bansenshukai, mention ninjas using disguises that matched their environment, further indicating functional clothing over uniform black attire.
The black-clad ninja trope persists because it simplifies visual storytelling in media, making it easier for audiences to recognize ninjas instantly, regardless of historical accuracy.
Modern forensic analysis of period textiles suggests that black dye was expensive and impractical for ninjas, who were often lower-class operatives, reinforcing the argument against all-black attire.
